title: 108_s2312
content:
The Act may be cited as the "SAFE-ID Act" or the "SAFE-ID Act". The Act, known as the "SAFE-ID Act," defines key terms such as business enterprise, country with adequate privacy protection, and health care business. A business enterprise is any organization established for profit, while a country with adequate privacy protection is certified by the FTC. Health care business includes hospitals, health maintenance organizations, and medical partnerships. The "SAFE-ID Act" defines personally identifiable information as including name, address, financial information, medical records, date of birth, phone number, email address, social security number, and mother's maiden name. The "SAFE-ID Act" defines personally identifiable information to include social security number, mother's maiden name, password, state identification information, and driver's license number. SEC. 3. TRANSMISSION OF INFORMATION. A business enterprise can transmit personally identifiable information of a US citizen to a foreign affiliate in a country with adequate privacy protection. Consent is required to transmit information to a foreign affiliate in a country without adequate privacy protection. The business enterprise is liable for any damages resulting from the misuse of personally identifiable information by itself or its foreign affiliates. The Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission will enforce this section through regulations and may impose fines for violations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE INFORMATION.

A health care business is responsible for damages from the misuse of personally identifiable information. They cannot end a relationship to avoid consent requirements. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will enforce regulations and impose fines for violations.

SEC. 5. CERTIFICATION. The Federal Trade Commission will certify countries with adequate privacy protection for personally identifiable information within 6 months of this Act. Criteria include infrastructure for detecting privacy violations. Countries meeting EU Data Protection Directive requirements will be certified unless laws are not commonly enforced. The Act will take effect 90 days after its enactment.
